journal-meta.journal-title: Transactions of the Institute of Measurement and Control

title-group.article-title: Design of a sliding mode controller for synchronizing chaotic systems with parameter and model uncertainties and external disturbances

article-meta.aff: 1Electrical Engineering Department, Urmia University of Technology, Iran
2Department of Mathematics, Mamaghan Branch, Islamic Azad University, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Hassan Feizi, Department of Mathematics, Mamaghan Branch, Islamic Azad University, Mamaghan, Iran Email: feizi60@gmail.com

abstract.p: Finite-time synchronization of two different uncertain chaotic systems using a new non-singular terminal sliding mode approach is studied in this paper. Both master and slave systems are perturbed by parameter and model uncertainties, as well as external disturbances. A novel non-singular terminal sliding manifold is introduced. Based on the Lyapunov stability theory and finite-time control idea, a robust sliding mode controller is designed. It is shown that both reaching and sliding phases have the finite-time convergence property. In other words, it is proved that the state trajectories of the slave system can reach the state trajectories of the master system in a given finite time. The robustness and applicability of the proposed technique are demonstrated by two illustrative examples.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In recent years, synchronization of chaotic systems has increasingly aroused the interest of many researchers, due to its powerful applications in many areas of physics and engineering, such as secure communication, lasers, information processing, power convertors, biological systems, economical systems and chemical reactions. A basic framework for chaos synchronization is the master-slave (drive-response) configuration. In this structure, the outputs of the master system are used to control the outputs of the slave system so that the state trajectories of the slave system track the state trajectories of the master system asymptotically. Since the pioneering work by Pecora and Carroll (1990), a wide variety of control approaches, such as sliding mode control (Aghababa and Heydari, 2011; Aghababa et al., 2011), optimal control (Ge and Yang, 2009), adaptive control (Guo et al., 2009), passive control (Wang and Liu, 2007), backstepping control (Yassen, 2007) and intermittent control (Zhu and Cui, 2010), have been presented for synchronizing chaotic systems.

In many practical situations, the parameters of the chaotic systems are inevitably perturbed by external inartificial factors and the values of them vary within some scope. Moreover, due to un-modeled dynamics, structural variations of the system and measurement and environment noises there are always some unknown model uncertainties and external disturbances in the chaotic systems’ dynamics. These uncertainties may cause system performance degradation and thereby destroy the synchronization. Therefore, investigation of the chaos synchronization between two uncertain chaotic systems is an important research issue (Chen and Zhang, 2007; Feki, 2009; Hyun et al., 2009; Lee et al., 2008; Lin et al., 2009; Pourmahmood et al., 2011; Wang and Wen, 2009).

However, most of the aforementioned works have focused on the study of asymptotical synchronization of chaotic systems (i.e. they have guaranteed that the slave system states can reach the master system states over an infinite time horizon), whereas in real world applications, it is more valuable to realize synchronization in a finite time. To attain fast convergence speed in a control system, the finite-time control technique is an effective strategy. Finite-time synchronization means the optimality in the settling time (Bhat and Bernstein, 2000). Furthermore, the finite-time control techniques have demonstrated better robustness and disturbance rejection properties (Bhat and Bernstein, 2000). Yu (2010) has proposed a finite-time control strategy based on the so-called control Lyapunov function (CLF) method for stabilization of three-dimensional chaotic systems. Recently, sliding mode techniques have been used to control chaos in a given finite time (Wang et al., 2009a,d; Xiang and Huangpu, 2010). Synchronization of the noise-perturbed Genesio–Tesi chaotic system via sliding mode control has been studied by Jianwen et al. (2010). In Li and Tian (2003), finite-time control techniques have been applied to synchronize two chaotic systems without considering the effects of model uncertainties and external disturbances. Wang et al. (2009b,c) have investigated the problem of finite-time synchronization of uncertain unified chaotic systems based on the CLF and finite-time control methods. A main drawback of the previous works is that the proposed synchronization strategies are not applicable for the finite-time synchronization of any two different chaotic systems in the presence of both model uncertainties and external disturbances. To the best knowledge of the authors, the general problem of finite-time chaos synchronization between two different chaotic systems with parameter and model uncertainties and external disturbances has not been well discussed in the literature.

In this paper, the problem of finite-time chaos synchronization between two different uncertain chaotic systems is investigated. Both master and slave systems are considered to be perturbed by parameter and model uncertainties, as well as external disturbances. Firstly, a novel non-singular terminal sliding manifold is proposed. It is shown that the proposed sliding surface can overcome the singularity problem of the traditional terminal sliding surfaces. The finite-time convergence and stability of the proposed sliding surface are analytically proved. Then, on the basis of the Lyapunov stability and finite-time control theory, a robust finite-time sliding mode control law is derived to guarantee the existence of the sliding motion in finite time. It is proved that the proposed sliding mode approach has finite-time convergence in both reaching and sliding phases. The exact value of the convergence time is also given. Finally, two illustrative examples are presented to validate the theoretical results of the paper.

sec.title: System description and problem statement
sec.p: In this section, firstly the system description and synchronization problem formulation are presented. Then, the accurate definition of the finite-time chaos synchronization concept and some necessary lemmas are given.
Consider two n-dimensional chaotic systems with parameter and model uncertainties and external disturbances as follows:
Master system:
Slave system:

where x(t)=[x1,x2,…,xn]T∈Rn×1 is the state vector of the master system, Ai∈R1×n is the ith row of an n×n constant matrix, ΔAi∈R1×n is the ith row of an n×n perturbation matrix, which represents the master system parametric uncertainties, fi(x)∈Rn×1→R is a continuous non-linear function, Δfi(x,t)∈Rn×1→R and dim(t)∈R are model uncertainties and external disturbance of the master system, respectively, y(t)=[y1,y2,…,yn]T∈Rn×1 is the state vector of the slave system, Bi∈R1×n is the ith row of an n×n constant matrix, ΔBi∈R1×n is the ith row of an n×n perturbation matrix, which represents the parametric uncertainties of the slave system, gi(y)∈Rn×1→R is a continuous non-linear function, Δgi(y,t)∈Rn×1→R and dis(t)∈R are model uncertainties and external disturbance of the slave system, respectively, and x(t)=[u1,u2,…,un]T∈Rn×1 is the vector of control inputs.

Remark 1. Most of the famous chaotic systems, such as the Rössler system, Liu system, Lorenz system, Lü system, Chen system, unified system, Genesio system, Duffing oscillator, Van der Pol oscillator, Chua’s circuits, Arneodo system and Rikitake system, as paradigms in the research of chaos, can be expressed by Equation (1).

Remark 2. In practical applications, the exact values of the parameter and model uncertainties and external disturbances cannot be determined in advance. However, the upper bounds of them are usually known in practice. In the well-known robust control theory, some constants, as the upper bounds of the model uncertainties and external disturbances, are used to design the robust controller. On the other hand, the state trajectories of the chaotic systems are always globally bounded. Motivated by the robust control theory and the global boundedness feature of the chaotic systems states, in this paper we assume that the model and parameter uncertainties and external disturbances are bounded by the norm of the state trajectories of the system plus a constant parameter. In this line, we made the following assumptions.
Assumption 1. The uncertainties ΔAi(t), Δfi(x,t), ΔBi(t) and Δgi(y,t) are bounded by
where ‖.‖ denotes the Euclidean norm in Rn and αi,βi,θi,ψi,ai and bi,i=1,2,…,n are given positive constants.
Assumption 2. In general it is assumed that the external disturbances are norm-bounded in C1, that is:
where Dim and Dis are two known positive constants.
As a result, using Equations (3)–(5), one can obtain

In this paper, the synchronization error between the master and slave systems is defined as e(t)=x(t)−y(t). Therefore, with subtracting Equation (2) from Equation (1), the synchronization error system is achieved as follows:

Finite-time chaos synchronization means that the states of the slave system converge to the states of the master system within a finite time. The accurate definition of the finite-time chaos synchronization is given below.

Definition 1. Consider the master and slave chaotic systems described by Equations (1) and (2), respectively. If there exists a constant T=T(e(0))>0, such that Limt→T‖e(t)‖=0 and ‖e(t)‖≡0, if t≥T, then the chaos synchronization between the chaotic systems (1) and (2) is realized in the finite time T.

It is clear that the finite-time synchronization problem is transformed to the equivalent problem of the finite-time stabilization of the error system (7). The main purpose of this paper is that for any given master chaotic system (1) and slave chaotic system (2) with model and parameter uncertainties and external disturbances, a proper control law u(t) is designed such that the finite-time stability of the resulting error system (7) can be achieved in the sense of Definition 1.

sec.title: Design procedure of the finite-time sliding mode controller
sec.p: In this section, a non-singular terminal robust sliding mode controller is designed to synchronize two different uncertain chaotic systems in finite time.

The sliding mode control approach is a robust control method that has many powerful characteristics, such as low sensitivity to external disturbances and robustness to the plant uncertainties due to the structural variations and un-modeled dynamics. The design procedure of a sliding mode controller is a two-stage process. The first stage is to choose a sliding surface with the desired properties and the second stage is to derive a discontinuous control law such that the system trajectories reach the sliding surface and remain on it forever.
Lemma 1. (Wang et al., 2009b,c). Assume that a continuous, positive-definite function V(t) satisfies the following differential inequality:
where c>0, 0<η<1 are two constants. Then, for any given t0, V(t) satisfies the following inequality:
and V(t)≡0,∀t>t1 with t1 given by

Lemma 3. Assume that a1,a2,…,an and 0<q<1 are real numbers, then we have
Proof. For n=1, it is obvious that the inequality (12) is satisfied. For n=2, it turns to Lemma 2.
It is supposed that for n=k the inequality (12) holds, that is:
For n=k+1, using the inequality (13), we have
Assuming |b|=|a1|+|a2|+…+|ak| and, from Lemma 2, one obtains
From (14) and (15), one can easily obtain
Therefore, by the principle of mathematical induction, it can be concluded that (12) is satisfied for any positive integer n. Hence, the proof is achieved completely.
In this paper, a non-singular terminal sliding surface is proposed as
where si(t)∈R+ and γi>0,0<μ<1 and 0<λ<μ are constants.
Once the system operates in the sliding mode, it satisfies the following equations (Utkin, 1992):
Consequently, the sliding mode dynamics is obtained as follows:
Theorem 1. Consider the terminal sliding mode dynamics (20). This system is finite-time stable and its state trajectories converge to zero in the finite time T1, given by
where ϑ=min{1/λγi(i=1,2,…,n)}.
Proof. Consider the following Lyapunov function candidate:
Taking the time derivative of the Lyapunov function candidate, one obtains
Replacing e·i(t) from (20) into the right-hand side of (23), this yields
According to ei(t)sign(ei)=|ei(t)|, one obtains
Based on 0<μ−λ<1 and Lemma 3, one has
Therefore, from Lemma 1, the error states ei(t),i=1,2,…,n converge to zero in the finite time T1=(∑i=1nei2(0))1−μ+λϑ(1−μ+λ). So, the proof is completed.

Remark 3. The traditional terminal sliding surfaces are usually designed as s(t)=C1e(t)+C2eq/p(t), where C1 and C2 are positive constants and p>q>0 are odd integers. Since the control inputs in these cases include the term eq/p−1(t), it is apparent that for e(t)<0, the fractional power q/p−1 may lead to the term eq/p−1(t)∉R, which leads to e·(t)∉R. The new proposed non-singular terminal sliding surface in (17) circumvents this singularity.

Once an appropriate non-singular terminal sliding surface is selected, the next step is to design a discontinuous control law to force the error system state trajectories to go on to the sliding surface in a finite time and remain on it evermore. Therefore, to ensure the occurrence of the sliding motion, the following control law is proposed:
where 0<ρ<1 and ki>0 are constants.

Theorem 2. Consider the synchronization error system represented by Equation (7). If this system is controlled by the control input ui(t),i=1,2,…,n in Equation (27), then the system state trajectories converge to the sliding surface si(t),i=1,2,…,n in a finite time T2, determined by
where ξ=min{λγiki(i=1,2,…,n}.
Proof. Choose a Lyapunov function candidate in the form of
Taking the time derivative of V2(t), we have
Replacing s·i(t) from (19) into (29), it yields
Inserting e·i(t) from (7) into the right-hand side of (31), we have
It is obvious that
Using inequality (6) and replacing ui(t) from (27) into (33), one has
After some mathematical manipulations, we have
Using Lemma 3, we have

Therefore, on the basis of Lemma 1, the error trajectories ei(t),i=1,2,…,n will converge to the sliding surface si(t),i=1,2,…,n in the finite time T2=(∑i=1nsi(0))1−ρξ(1−ρ). Hence, the proof is achieved completely.

Remark 4. According to the Theorems 1 and 2, the finite-time sliding mode control law (27) with the non-singular terminal sliding surface (17) can make the slave system (2) reach the master system (1) in the finite time T=T1+T2.

Remark 5. The proposed controller is also applicable for the chaos synchronization between two identical uncertain chaotic systems with different initial values, if systems (1) and (2) satisfy A=B and f(.)=g(.).

Remark 6. Since the control input (27) contains the sign function as a hard switcher, undesirable chattering may occur. In order to avoid the chattering, the sign function is approximated by the hyperbolic tanh(εei) function, where ε is a positive constant.

sec.title: Numerical simulations
sec.p: In this section, the robustness and usefulness of the proposed finite-time control technique in synchronizing two different chaotic systems with uncertain parameters, model uncertainties and external disturbance are validated using two illustrative examples. Simulations are performed using MATLAB software. In both examples, the constant ε is set to 100.

sec.title: Case 1: Finite-time synchronization of the Chen and Lü chaotic systems
sec.p: In this example, the chaotic Chen and Lü systems are selected to be synchronized using the proposed finite-time sliding mode control scheme. It is assumed that the Chen system is the master system and the Lü system is the slave system. The uncertain Chen and Lü systems are described by the following non-linear equations.
Uncertain Chen system:
Uncertain Lü system with control inputs:
Subsequently, the following uncertainties and disturbances are considered in the simulation:

The constants λ,μ and ρ are selected equal to 0.9, 0.8 and 0.7, respectively. The switching gain k is chosen as [10,10,10]. The constants γ1,γ2 and γ3 are all set equal to 2. The initial values of the Chen and Lü systems are randomly chosen as x1(0)=4,x2(0)=6,x3(0)=5 and y1(0)=2,y2(0)=4,y3(0)=3, respectively.

The synchronization errors between the Chen and Lü systems are displayed in Figure 1, where the controller is applied at t=5s. One can see that the synchronization errors converge to zero rapidly, which implies that the trajectories of the Lü system approach the trajectories of the Chen system within a finite time, as displayed in Figure 2. Figure 3 illustrates the applied control inputs (27). It is seen that the control inputs are feasible in practice.

caption.p: Synchronization errors between the Chen and Lü systems.
State trajectories of the Chen and Lü systems.
Time histories of the applied control inputs in case 1.

sec.p: Remark 7. The parameters αi,βi,θi,ψi,ai,bi,Dim and Dis,i=1,2,3 can be determined such that the inequalities (3)–(5) in Assumptions 1 and 2 are satisfied. As a result, one can check that α1=θ1=0.5, α2=θ2=0.3, α3=θ3=0.4, β1=ψ1=0.4, β2=ψ2=0.1, β3=ψ3=0.2, a1=b1=0.2, a2=b2=0.1, a3=b3=0.5 and D1m=D2m=D3m=D1s=D2s=D3s=0.1 satisfy the conditions of Assumptions 1 and 2.

Remark 8. One can set the switching gain k to be a reasonable positive vector constant. On the other hand, according to the control input (27), it is obvious that the control effort is proportional to the value of k. This means that a small k results in a small control effort and a large k leads to a large control input. Therefore, the switching gain k may be selected such that the control input is not very large, considering the designer requirements and practical implementation conditions.

sec.title: Case 2: Finite-time synchronization of the Rikitake and Rössler chaotic systems
sec.p: This example demonstrates the effectiveness and efficiency of the proposed technique in synchronization of the chaotic Rikitake and Rössler systems. In this case, the Rikitake system drives the Rössler system. The Rikitake and Rössler systems are expressed by the following non-linear equations.
Uncertain Rikitake system:
Uncertain Rössler system with control inputs:

In this example, all controller parameters and system uncertainties and disturbances are applied the same as those in case 1. The initial values of the Rikitake and Rössler systems are randomly chosen as x1(0)=2,x2(0)=4,x3(0)=6 and y1(0)=4,y2(0)=6,y3(0)=8, respectively.

Figure 4 shows the synchronization errors between the Rikitake and Rössler systems, where the control inputs are turned on at t=5 s. It is observed that the synchronization errors approach zero quickly, which implies that the trajectories of the Rikitake system converge to the trajectories of the Rössler system within a finite time, as depicted in Figure 5. The time histories of the applied control inputs (27) are plotted in Figure 6. One can see that the controller can be implemented in practical applications.

caption.p: Synchronization errors between the Rikitake and Rössler systems.
State trajectories of the Rikitake and Rössler systems.
Time histories of the applied control inputs in case 2.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: In the present paper, a finite-time sliding mode approach is proposed to synchronize two different uncertain chaotic systems. Firstly, a novel non-singular terminal sliding manifold is introduced. Then, on the basis of the finite-time control technique, a robust finite-time sliding mode control law is designed. Finite-time stability of the closed-loop system is mathematically proved. Finally, numerical simulations confirm that the proposed controller works well for the finite-time synchronization of two different chaotic systems with parameter and model uncertainties and external disturbances.
